questions.text: A 6-year-old girl with polycystic kidney disease is started on a new medication after receiving a kidney transplant from a matched, unrelated donor. Two days after starting the medication, laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 17,500/mm3 (90% segmented neutrophils, 4% bands, 1% eosinophils, 3% lymphocytes, and 1% monocytes). Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of these laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rituximab, an anti-CD20+ biologic, prevents the maturation and differentiation of B cells via antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity. Through its B-cell cytotoxic action, rituximab can cause leukopenia and is not commonly administered after renal or other solid organ transplantations.
Image Description:

- Complement-dependent cytotoxicity (CDC): The recruitment of proteins of the complement system (e.g., C1) results in the formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC), disrupting the cell membrane and causing B-cell lysis.

- Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC): Effector immune cells (e.g, natural killer cells, macrophages) bind to the Fc tail of rituximab with their Fc receptors and kill the B cells.

- Direct apoptosis: The binding of rituximab to the CD20 receptor can also lead to direct induction of apoptosis.

B) CORRECT:

The presence of neutrophilia without left shift (no increase in bands) is classic for glucocorticoid-induced leukocytosis. Glucocorticoids inhibit the attachment of neutrophils to their endothelial surface receptors, resulting in demargination. Other minor mechanisms of glucocorticoid-induced leukocytosis include delayed apoptosis and a slight increase in bone marrow production, which typically occur 24 hours after administration.

C) INCORRECT:

Abciximab is a glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor antagonist that prevents platelet adhesion and aggregation. The primary side effect of this class of drugs is bleeding, not neutrophilia.

D) INCORRECT:

Ganciclovir is an anti-viral medication widely used in the treatment of CMV in immunocompromised hosts. It is associated with bone marrow suppression and would present with leukopenia, not leukocytosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Administration of EPO, a medication used to stimulate erythropoiesis, would lead to an elevation in circulating RBCs, not WBCs. EPO is not commonly administered after renal or other solid organ transplantations.

F) INCORRECT:

Tacrolimus is an immunosuppressant that acts primarily to inhibit expression of IL-2, a cytokine responsible for T-cell proliferation. It is commonly used after organ transplantation to prevent acute rejection. Tacrolimus can cause neutropenia, not neutrophilia, in kidney transplant recipients.
questions.hint: This patient's laboratory results show neutrophilia with the presence of immature neutrophils, without a prominent left shift.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the office because of an 8-month history of cough, night sweats, shortness of breath, and fatigue. He has also had a 9-kg (19.8-lb) weight loss during this time. He appears pale. Abdominal examination shows hepatosplenomegaly. His leukocyte count is 80,000/mm3 and his leukocyte alkaline phosphatase level is increased. A peripheral blood smear shows > 82% neutrophils with band forms and immature and mature neutrophil precursors. An x-ray of the chest shows a 9-mm right hilar nodule. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A leukemoid reaction is characterized by profound leukocytosis with a proportionate increase in all elements of the myeloid lineage (neutrophils, immature and mature precursors) and elevated leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP), as seen in this patient. B symptoms, chronic fatigue, and hepatosplenomegaly are indicative of an underlying malignancy. The pulmonary nodule on chest x-ray, along with cough and shortness of breath are highly suggestive of a leukemoid reaction secondary to lung cancer. Leukemoid reactions can mimic leukemia but are typically due to infections (e.g., C. difficile colitis, whooping cough), drugs (e.g., glucocorticoids), and certain solid tumors (e.g., kidney cancer, Hodgkin lymphoma, and melanoma).

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has clinical features of tuberculosis, such as weight loss, night sweats, fatigue, and cough. Some cases of tuberculosis may also cause a leukemoid reaction with a proportionate increase in all elements of the myeloid lineage and elevated LAP. However, patients with tuberculosis usually have a travel history to endemic areas (e.g., India, Indonesia, or China). In addition, the chest x-ray in tuberculosis would typically show cavitary lesions near the apex, which is not the case here.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has some features that are typical of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), such as night sweats, weight loss, fatigue, hepatosplenomegaly, and leukocytosis with an increase in elements of the myeloid lineage. However, this patient presents with an increased LAP level; in CML, the LAP is usually decreased.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) may also present with fatigue, fever, and hepatosplenomegaly and/or leukocytosis. While this patient presents with a proportionate increase in all elements of the myeloid lineage, ALL would affect the lymphoid cell line, typically showing a highly increased number of lymphoblasts in the WBC differential. In addition, ALL most commonly affects children 2–5 years of age, making a different diagnosis more likely in this 60-year-old man.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has clinical features of sarcoidosis, such as weight loss, night sweats, fatigue, and cough. Some cases of sarcoidosis may also cause a leukemoid reaction with a proportionate increase in all elements of the myeloid lineage and elevated LAP. However, he does not have other typical features like peripheral lymphadenopathy and/or iridocyclitis. Moreover, chest x-ray would typically show bilateral hilar and mediastinal nodal enlargement with reticulonodular opacities, which is not the case here.
questions.hint: The bone marrow biopsy would likely show hyperplasia with proliferation of all myeloid elements.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of fatigue. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 13.3 g/dL, a serum creatinine concentration of 0.9 mg/dL, and a serum alkaline phosphatase concentration of 130 U/L. Laboratory evaluation of which of the following parameters would be most helpful in determining the cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cancer antigen 27-29 (CA 27-29) may be elevated in breast cancer. Although high levels of CA 27-29 can indicate liver or bone metastases, which may also cause elevated ALP, CA 27-29 is a nonspecific parameter that can also be elevated in various other cancers and noncancerous conditions. Therefore, CA 27-29 cannot be used to determine the cause of this patient's symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is an enzyme that catalyzes the reversible conversion of lactate to pyruvate and is elevated in any case of cell damage or disease with increased cell turnover. LDH would not help in determining the underlying cause of this patient's symptoms because it is a rather nonspecific marker that can be elevated in various conditions, including malignancies, hemolytic anemia, hepatocyte injury, and infarction.

C) INCORRECT:

Ferritin is responsible for iron storage and acts as an acute phase reactant. Ferritin would not help in determining the underlying cause of this patient's symptoms because it is a rather nonspecific marker that can be elevated in various conditions, including systemic inflammation, malignant disease, anemia of chronic disease, and sideroblastic anemia. A different investigation is more appropriate in this patient with normal hemoglobin and increased ALP.

D) CORRECT:

In a patient with increased ALP, gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT) would be the most appropriate test to differentiate a disease of the hepatobiliary system from a disease of the bone. Simultaneous elevation in both ALP and GGT would signify a liver or biliary tract pathology. If ALP is elevated as a result of increased bone turnover, GGT levels would be normal. Increased GGT with normal ALP is characteristic of heavy alcohol use.

E) INCORRECT:

Calcitriol assays are indicated to diagnose vitamin D deficiency (osteomalacia/rickets), which can present with fatigue and increased ALP (due to secondary hyperparathyroidism). However, hepatic disorders are also associated with fatigue and increased ALP. Therefore, a different test is more appropriate to determine the tissue of origin of ALP before investigations pertinent to bone disorders are considered.
questions.hint: The patient has nonspecific symptoms and an elevation of serum alkaline phosphatase that may be associated with liver disease or bone pathology. To determine the underlying disease, a specific laboratory marker is needed.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 1-week history of fever and fatigue. During this period, she has also had decreased appetite and a 1.5-kg (3.5-lb) weight loss. Her temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows cervical lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 15 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 21,000/mm3, and a platelet count of 320,000/mm3. A peripheral blood smear is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the findings on this patient's peripheral blood smear?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has many nonspecific clinical features of acute infection, including fever, fatigue, decreased appetite, weight loss, tachycardia, lymphadenopathy, and leukocytosis. Her young age, in combination with the specific finding of cervical lymphadenopathy, raises suspicion for infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. However, peripheral blood smear findings for acute viral infections typically show lymphocytosis, not neutrophilia. Furthermore, a classic finding in infectious mononucleosis is atypical lymphocytes (i.e., reactive T cells with abundant cytoplasm), which are not seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Burkitt lymphoma is a B-cell lymphoma most commonly seen in children and can cause localized lymphadenopathy. However, the characteristic histopathologic finding associated with this condition is the presence of tingible body macrophages scattered diffusely within a sheet of uniform neoplastic cells in a sample of the tumor, not neutrophilia on a peripheral blood smear. In addition, Burkitt lymphoma does not typically cause fever, fatigue, decreased appetite, or weight loss.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) may cause fever, fatigue, decreased appetite, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, and leukocytosis, all of which are seen here. ALL is also most commonly seen in children (peak incidence of 2–5 years of age). However, the characteristic peripheral blood smear finding associated with ALL is an abundance of large, immature lymphocytes (i.e., lymphoblasts), not neutrophilia. In addition, this patient does not have other typical findings of ALL, including pallor, bleeding, bruising, bone pain, and hepatosplenomegaly.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has many nonspecific clinical features of acute infection, including fever, fatigue, decreased appetite, weight loss, tachycardia, lymphadenopathy, and leukocytosis. The peripheral blood smear finding of neutrophilia raises suspicion for a bacterial etiology. In response to bacterial infection, neutrophils demarginate from the vascular endothelium and are released from the bone marrow. This results in an increased concentration of neutrophils in the blood (i.e., neutrophilia) as they migrate to sites of infection to clear bacteria via phagocytosis. The bone marrow also increases neutrophil production, which can result in the presence of immature predecessors, such as band cells, in the blood (i.e., left shift).

E) INCORRECT:

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) may cause fatigue, decreased appetite, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, and leukocytosis, all of which are seen in this patient. However, the characteristic peripheral blood smear finding associated with AML is an abundance of immature myeloid precursors (i.e., myeloblasts), not neutrophilia. In addition, AML most commonly develops in older adults (peak incidence of 65 years of age) and often causes pallor, weakness, bleeding, and hepatosplenomegaly, none of which are seen here.

F) INCORRECT:

This patient has many nonspecific clinical features of acute infection, including fever, fatigue, decreased appetite, weight loss, tachycardia, lymphadenopathy, and leukocytosis. However, acute parasitic infections do not typically lead to neutrophilia, which would be seen on a peripheral blood smear; they are more commonly associated with eosinophilia.
questions.hint: The peripheral blood smear shows neutrophilia.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man with mild asthma reports a 4-day history of shortness of breath that does not improve with the use of his albuterol and budesonide inhalers. He does not take other medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years.
He is afebrile, and his condition is hemodynamically stable, but he has slight tachypnea and expiratory wheezing. His oxygen saturation is 93% while he is breathing ambient air. No splenomegaly is found.
Laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range



Leukocyte count (per mm3)
14,000
4500–11,000


Neutrophil count (per mm3)
9100
1900–7600


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
14.2
13.5–17.5


Platelet count (per mm3)
260,000
150,000–350,000


Review of a peripheral-blood smear shows no evidence of myeloid immaturity.
A complete blood count obtained 2 years ago during an annual checkup showed similarly increased leukocyte and neutrophil counts.
A chest radiograph is normal.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s neutrophilia?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Cigarette smoking is a common cause of mild leukocytosis, and the more packs of cigarettes smoked per day, the greater the elevation in the absolute neutrophil count. Normalization of the leukocyte count may occur after as little as one year to as long as several years after the cessation of smoking, but may take up to five years. Inflammation related to smoking has been invoked as a cause of neutrophilic leukocytosis, but the exact mechanism is unknown.

Key learning point: The most typical cause of long-standing mild leukocytosis and neutrophilia in a patient with asthma who smokes cigarettes is cigarette smoking.

B) INCORRECT:

The patient's stable clinical course suggests that an undiagnosed chronic infection, which can be associated with bronchiectasis, is unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Inhaled glucocorticoids reduce airway neutrophilia. Systemic high-dose glucocorticoid use can be associated with a mild neutrophilia (average increase in absolute neutrophil count of 4000 per mm3), but this effect is rarely seen with inhaled glucocorticoids because the systemically absorbed dose is generally insufficient to affect neutrophil levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Hereditary neutrophilia is an extremely rare disorder caused by an autosomal mutation in the CSF3R gene, which results in a constitutively active granulocyte colony-stimulating factor receptor. This condition manifests with neutrophilia and splenomegaly.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic neutrophilic leukemia is associated with neutrophilia and splenomegaly and with blood counts that are likely to worsen over time.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man with HIV infection is hospitalized for evaluation of diarrhea and a fever of 38.3°C. His blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 110 beats per minute. His abdomen is diffusely tender to palpation, without rebound or guarding.
The patient’s HIV infection was diagnosed 5 years ago. He has remained on efavirenz, tenofovir, and emtricitabine since then. He takes no other medications. His HIV viral load recently increased to more than 50 copies/mL, and his CD4 count recently decreased to <100 cells per mm3 (reference range, 400–1600).
On day 2 of his hospitalization, he is diagnosed with cytomegalovirus enteritis, according to a biopsy of mucosal ulcers during a colonoscopy. On hospital day 3, he is started on intravenous ganciclovir.
By day 10 of his hospitalization, his diarrhea has improved significantly and he is afebrile.
Laboratory testing shows the following results:



At admission
At day 10
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
12.8
12.2
13.5–17.5


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
4400
1400
4500–11,000



Absolute neutrophil count (per mm3)
2500
800
1900–7600


Platelet count (per mm3)
110 x 103

103 x 103

150–400 x 103



Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
0.5
0.6
0.3–1.0


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.3
1.2
0.8–1.3


What is the most likely cause of this patient’s new hematologic findings?

choices.text: Treatment with efavirenz, tenofovir, and emtricitabine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mycobacterium avium complex infection is unlikely in a patient who is improving clinically and who has an obvious drug-related cause of neutropenia.

B) INCORRECT:

Both HIV infection and antiretroviral therapy can cause neutropenia, especially if zidovudine is used. However, this is unlikely when the onset of neutropenia is acute.

C) INCORRECT:

Both HIV infection and antiretroviral therapy can cause neutropenia, especially if zidovudine is used. However, this is unlikely when the onset of neutropenia is acute.

D) CORRECT:

Adverse medication effects are the most common cause of neutropenia in patients with HIV infection and can usually be identified when the onset of neutropenia occurs after initiation of a new medication. Because ganciclovir frequently causes neutropenia, monitoring of complete blood counts during ganciclovir therapy is recommended.

Key learning point: A serious hematologic adverse effect of treatment with ganciclovir is neutropenia.

E) INCORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus infection can cause neutropenia as a result of direct bone-marrow involvement, but cytomegalovirus-associated neutropenia should improve, not deteriorate, following appropriate treatment.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman with a history of hypothyroidism, hyperlipidemia, and migraine headaches presents for a screening physical. Her current medications are acetaminophen, atorvastatin, and levothyroxine; she also takes sumatriptan as needed. She feels well overall, other than mild arthralgias that are long-standing.
She identifies herself as Black on the patient intake questionnaire and reports that she is a kindergarten teacher. She has never smoked and rarely drinks alcohol (<1 drink/week).
Her physical examination and vital signs are unremarkable. She has no palpable adenopathy or organomegaly.
Routine laboratory testing reveals a leukocyte count of 1900 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000) with an absolute neutrophil count of 1100 per mm3 (1900–7600), a hemoglobin concentration of 13.1 g/dL (12.0–16.0), and a platelet count of 334,000 per mm3 (150,000–350,000). A peripheral smear shows moderate neutropenia but no other cellular evidence of immaturity, dysplasia, or blasts.
A review of the patient's electronic medical record reveals that her absolute neutrophil count has ranged from 800 to 1400 per mm3 for the past 8 years. She has had respiratory infections once or twice per year but no serious infections requiring hospitalization.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate to address this patient’s neutrophil count?

choices.text: Order flow cytometry to detect glycosylphosphatidylinositol-anchored proteins
Measure serum vitamin B12, folic acid, and copper levels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Flow cytometry for glycosylphosphatidylinositol-anchored proteins is used to diagnose paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), an acquired stem-cell disorder in which red cells are prone to complement-mediated lysis. Intravascular hemolysis and nitric oxide depletion lead to a variety of symptoms, including anemia, abdominal pain, dysphagia, and thrombosis. PNH can also be seen in association with bone-marrow failure syndromes, such as aplastic anemia and myelodysplastic syndrome. PNH is very rare. Isolated neutropenia is not a typical manifestation of PNH and should not prompt testing in an otherwise asymptomatic patient.

B) INCORRECT:

A bone-marrow biopsy is appropriate to evaluate progressive or severe cytopenias of unclear etiology. However, it is unlikely to add diagnostic value in an asymptomatic patient with long-standing unchanged neutropenia. Patients with constitutional neutropenia generally have unremarkable bone marrow.

C) INCORRECT:

Use of nearly any medication can cause neutropenia in a small percentage of patients. Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, antibiotics, antithyroid medications, and antiepileptic drugs are common offenders. The mechanisms are diverse and include direct bone-marrow damage and immune-mediated destruction. Causality is difficult to determine. Medication-induced neutropenia should be considered when severe neutropenia occurs after a new medication is started. In this particular case, sumatriptan is not commonly implicated in neutropenia, and the patient's cytopenias are chronic. Thus, withholding this medication would not aid in her evaluation and might even be harmful. Her other medications are also not associated with isolated neutropenia.

D) CORRECT:

Neutropenia can occur in a wide variety of disorders, including nutritional deficiencies, primary marrow disorders, comorbid collagen-vascular diseases, alcohol use disorder, and various infections. Given the broad differential, the clinician must closely examine the affected patient, the chronicity of the neutropenia, and the peripheral blood smear to focus the evaluation and avoid unnecessary testing.

This patient’s neutropenia is long-standing and stable. Furthermore, she is without recurrent infections, additional cytopenias, or constitutional symptoms. Such a history — particularly in a patient of African, Middle Eastern, or Mediterranean descent — is compatible with what was formerly called benign ethnic neutropenia and has more recently been termed constitutional neutropenia or typical neutrophil count with Fy(a-b‑) status. It stems from a genetic polymorphism in the erythrocyte Duffy antigen receptor for chemokines (DARC) gene. This polymorphism provides protection against malaria but also induces neutropenia through mechanisms that are not fully understood. Although testing for DARC polymorphisms is available, it is rarely necessary: one can reasonably assume the diagnosis in the appropriate clinical context, and it is asymptomatic and requires no specific therapy.

Key learning point: Asymptomatic isolated absolute neutrophil counts below the laboratory reference range are characteristically seen in patients of certain ethnicities, including people of African descent, who typically do not express the Duffy allele (Fy(a-b‑)).

E) INCORRECT:

Although nutritional deficiencies can cause cytopenias, they are less likely in this case. Vitamin B12 deficiency may cause macrocytic anemia or pancytopenia, and hypersegmented neutrophils are sometimes evident in the peripheral blood smear, but isolated neutropenia is not a common manifestation. Folate deficiency is exceedingly rare in the United States, given fortification of the food supply with folic acid, but it can occur in certain settings, including alcohol use disorder, severe malnutrition, and the use of certain medications (e.g., methotrexate and phenytoin). Copper deficiency can result in myeloneuropathy and cytopenias, but it is extremely rare outside of patients with predisposing conditions, such as gastric bypass, chronic gastrointestinal disease, and excess zinc supplementation. Because copper is absorbed in the stomach and small intestine, patients with abnormalities in these areas can be at risk for deficiency.

questions.text:
A 12-month-old girl presents to the emergency department (ED) with fever, mouth sores, and fatigue. Her parents report that several children at her day-care center have recently been diagnosed with viral gastroenteritis. They note that yesterday, she developed a fever of 39.1°C and ulcers in her mouth — and today, she has been very fatigued and is not eating or drinking. During the past 6 months, she has had six similar episodes but no serious infections.
On physical examination, she is fussy but consolable. She has a temperature of 39.5°C, a heart rate of 130 beats per minute, dry mucous membranes, mildly erythematous tympanic membranes, erythematous ulcerations in the oropharynx, and anterior cervical lymphadenopathy.
A complete blood count yields the following results, which are similar to findings from her last episode:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
4900
6000–17,500


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
12.0
10.5–13.5


Hematocrit (%)
35
33–39


Platelet count (per mm3)
400,000
150,000–450,000


Neutrophils (%)
4
17–49


Lymphocytes (%)
69
67–77


Monocytes (%)
20
4–11


Basophils (%)
3
0–3


Eosinophils (%)
2
0–8


Intravenous fluids are started, blood cultures are obtained, and cefepime is started.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Monitor complete blood count with differential daily, then twice weekly for 6 to 8 weeks
Observe, with no further intervention at this time

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient presents with painful mouth ulcers, fever, and volume depletion in the setting of neutropenia. Drawing a blood culture and treating with empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics is appropriate for a breadth of causes of neutropenia; however, it is important to understand the underlying cause of the patient’s neutropenia. The recurrent nature of her symptoms suggests a diagnosis of cyclic neutropenia; however, other causes of neutropenia should be ruled out and the neutropenic cycles documented.

Cyclic neutropenia is a rare condition that is caused by a mutation in the neutrophil elastase gene and is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern (although sporadic cases can occur through new mutations). Onset usually occurs during the first years of life and is characterized by recurrent episodes of fever and neutropenia on a consistent cycle, usually every 21 to 30 days. The most common symptoms during these episodes (in addition to fever) are painful mouth ulcers, pharyngitis, sinusitis, and cellulitis. Complete blood counts usually show a nadir absolute neutrophil count close to zero and a monocytosis lasting for 3 to 5 days before recovery. In this patient, monitoring complete blood counts to document these cycles is warranted.

Once other causes of neutropenia have been ruled out and cyclic neutropenia has been documented, granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (GCSF) is the typical treatment. GCSF is given either daily or every other day, with the goal of shortening the duration of severe neutropenia and associated infection risk. GCSF is given in lower doses in cyclic neutropenia than in chemotherapy-induced neutropenia.

Patients with cyclic neutropenia typically improve as they get older, and the severity of their symptoms decreases after puberty. Until then, close monitoring is required. Observation alone would be appropriate for benign familial neutropenia, which also manifests during the first year of life but is typically asymptomatic and diagnosed on the basis of a complete blood count or during a mild viral illness. Although coxsackie viral infection might be suspected in a child with oral ulcers (and would also be managed with observation alone), this patient’s ulcers are related to her neutropenia.

Key learning point: In managing cyclic neutropenia, the first step is monitoring of differential patterns to confirm the diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with cyclic neutropenia typically improve as they get older, and the severity of their symptoms decreases after puberty. Until then, close monitoring is required. Observation alone would be appropriate for benign familial neutropenia, which also manifests during the first year of life but is typically asymptomatic and diagnosed on the basis of a complete blood count or during a mild viral illness.

C) INCORRECT:

Once cyclic neutropenia has been documented, granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (GCSF) is the typical treatment. GCSF is given either daily or every other day, with the goal of shortening the duration of severe neutropenia and associated infection risk. GCSF is given in lower doses in cyclic neutropenia than in chemotherapy-induced neutropenia.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids (e.g., dexamethasone) and intravenous immunoglobulins are not beneficial in patients with cyclic neutropenia. These medications have been considered in the treatment of autoimmune neutropenia but have limited efficacy in that setting. Although autoimmune neutropenia would initially be in the differential diagnosis for this patient, once the cycles of neutropenia (symptomatic or asymptomatic) are established, cyclic neutropenia becomes the more likely diagnosis. Antineutrophil antibodies are present in many, although not all, patients with autoimmune neutropenia.

E) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids (e.g., dexamethasone) and intravenous immunoglobulins are not beneficial in patients with cyclic neutropenia. These medications have been considered in the treatment of autoimmune neutropenia but have limited efficacy in that setting. Although autoimmune neutropenia would initially be in the differential diagnosis for this patient, once the cycles of neutropenia (symptomatic or asymptomatic) are established, cyclic neutropenia becomes the more likely diagnosis. Antineutrophil antibodies are present in many, although not all, patients with autoimmune neutropenia.

Although nutritional deficiencies can cause cytopenias, they are less likely in this case. Vitamin B12 deficiency may cause macrocytic anemia or pancytopenia, and hypersegmented neutrophils are sometimes evident in the peripheral blood smear, but isolated neutropenia is not a common manifestation. Folate deficiency is exceedingly rare in the United States, given fortification of the food supply with folic acid, but it can occur in certain settings, including alcohol use disorder, severe malnutrition, and the use of certain medications (e.g., methotrexate and phenytoin). Copper deficiency can result in myeloneuropathy and cytopenias, but it is extremely rare outside of patients with predisposing conditions, such as gastric bypass, chronic gastrointestinal disease, and excess zinc supplementation. Because copper is absorbed in the stomach and small intestine, patients with abnormalities in these areas can be at risk for deficiency.
questions.hint: Neutropenia can occur in a wide variety of disorders, including nutritional deficiencies, primary marrow disorders, comorbid collagen-vascular diseases, alcohol use disorder, and various infections.
